title: Tribunals and Quasi-Judicial Bodies in India

information.title: Definition
information.description: Tribunals are specialized courts established to handle specific types of disputes. Quasi-judicial bodies are administrative agencies that have powers resembling those of courts but are not part of the regular court system.

information.title: Constitutional Basis
information.description: Articles 323A and 323B of the Constitution, introduced by the 42nd Amendment in 1976, provide for the establishment of administrative tribunals and tribunals for other matters respectively.

information.title: Types of Tribunals
information.description: India has various tribunals including the National Green Tribunal, Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, Central Administrative Tribunal, Armed Forces Tribunal, and National Company Law Tribunal, among others.

information.title: Functions
information.description: Tribunals and quasi-judicial bodies adjudicate disputes related to specific areas of law or administration. They aim to provide speedy and specialized justice, reducing the burden on regular courts.

information.title: Composition
information.description: Tribunals typically consist of a chairperson and members who have expertise in the relevant field. The chairperson is usually a retired judge or a person qualified to be a judge of a high court or the Supreme Court.

information.title: Appeals
information.description: Decisions of tribunals can generally be appealed in High Courts or the Supreme Court. However, some tribunals like the National Green Tribunal have their orders directly appealable to the Supreme Court.
